question:
Success in formal "pen and paper" examinations is often seen to be a sign of intelligence.
To what extent do you agree with the view that formal examinations measure intelligence?
Give reasons for your answer and include any relevant examples from your own
knowledge or experience.
Write at least 250 words.
text: The validity of "pen and paper" examination was always a debatable issue and with the shift of emphasis towards practical knowledge, it has
become a controversial topic. Masses consider that scoring good in written exams in itself depicts the intelligence level of an individual. I disagree with

the above-mentioned notion because just cramming the theories is a sign of good retention power and not intelligence. Moreover, it will not help an individual to survive in the real world, not limited to the job market.

These days most the institutes are conducting aptitude tests to determine a student's IQ Level. These tests focus only on theory and hardly include any practical scenarios or case studies. Similarly, in most educational institutes, be it a school or a B-School, the complete focus is on designing the curriculum with maximum weightage given to written exams. They hardly put effort to
have hands-on projects which can help a student in understanding the practical viability of the theories learnt so far. Resulting which, the pupils just
cram the books and lessons covered in the class, write the exam and pass. The one who is able to cram the best is awarded the first rank and considered the most intelligent person in the batch.
But such students are unable to cope with the actual job market. In the current scenario, most of the companies are considering marks just as an
eligibility criterion and nothing else. They are concentrating on the practical skills and vocational training an individual has been through. The

interviewers are preferring a candidate with relevant practical experience than just good marks.Because as per corporates, an intelligent person is the one who can survive and generate profit in the business world and this is impossible without practical knowledge. For instance, many known
businessmen have never been to B-School and with their intelligence, they are able to rule the business world. One of them is Mukesh Ambani who is the richest person in Asia.
To recapitulate, I believe that colleges and schools should focus on practical knowledge and replace "pen and paper" examinations with "Hands-on"
examinations. They should include vocational training in the academic curriculum as most of the firms are demanding more technical experts than
the one with the highest score because as per them, the definition of intelligence is altogether different.
